Description: Cast fitting for crown or wig of large figure (possibly Osiris?) in copper alloy; representing a raised cobra (uraeus), with tail arranged in a loop; eyes, mouth and axial ridge on front of hood modelled and incised; front of hood divided by curved ribs in hollow sections which were supposed to receive coloured paste and/or glass inlays; traces of such inlays remains in some sections of the hood, light green-blue in colour; small hole through tail to fix the uraeus on statue; metal quite well preserved, though end of tail broken, and inlays damaged or missing.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Several fittings made off copper alloy, sometimes with glass inlays like on this example, were discovered in Naukratis: they consist mainly in elements of crowns, but also false beards. Such fitting implies the presence of a relatively large statue of an Egyptian deity, probably life size or even larger statue in the case of this specimen (Masson forthcoming). Fittings in the shape of uraeus (single or pair) in copper alloy found in the Delta are listed in Weiss 2012, 876-880 (see esp. Nr. 1731 for this specimen). For other uraei with coloured glass inlays, see for example: Grenier 2002, 176-177, pl. XLVIII. Grenier, J.-C. 2002, Les Bronzes du Museo Gregoriano Egizio, Vatican City. Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds), Naukratis in Context II: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings. Proceedings of the Second Naukratis Project Workshop held at the British Museum, 22nd – 23rd June 2013. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten: Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Weiss 2012 / Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland (p. 954, Nr. 1731)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.234) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia
